snippet: Six days after the attack on Charlie Hebdo, Muslim groups in France, Egypt and elsewhere said the newspaper’s new cover would exacerbate tensions.
abstract: French satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo reveals its new cover depicting Prophet Muhammad and instantly restarts debate matching free speech against religious beliefs that has roiled Europe since the Paris terrorist massacre of 12 people; Muslim groups warn cartoon will increase tensions.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Maïa de la Baume and Alan Cowell from Paris, Kareem Fahim and Merna Thomas from Cairo, and Rick Gladstone and Ravi Somaiya from New York.

lead_paragraph: Six days after the attack on Charlie Hebdo, Muslim groups in France, Egypt and elsewhere said the newspaper’s new cover would exacerbate tensions.

headline.main: Charlie Hebdo’s Defiant Muhammad Cover Fuels Debate on Free Speech
headline.print_headline: With New Cover of French Paper, New Set of Fears
